text: @FeuFollet_ Yes, if they want to. But Liberia is tight-knit and very social and their community is almost certain to find out.

text: A lot of people felt that the WHO figures were far too high when they came out. They were based on the idea that awareness wouldn't work.

user.description: Journalist, human rights advocate, occasional Ebola survivor.
user.name: ashoka

text: It looks like A. the Ebola crisis is now worst in Guinea and Sierra Leone, and B. WHO projections from Sept. were way off.

user.description: Journalist, human rights advocate, occasional Ebola survivor.
user.name: ashoka

text: Very very tentatively optimistic that maybe Liberia is getting a handle on Ebola. But we can't rest with sending supplies and doctors.

user.description: Journalist, human rights advocate, occasional Ebola survivor.
user.name: ashoka

text: Here's why I don't buy that though: at that point people didn't believe Ebola was real. Now nearly everyone does, and they take precautions.

user.description: Journalist, human rights advocate, occasional Ebola survivor.
user.name: ashoka

text: Another worry is whether this dip in cases mirrors the early summer dip before the explosion in July and August.

user.description: Journalist, human rights advocate, occasional Ebola survivor.
user.name: ashoka

text: Families in late Sept would wait outside ETUs furious and in tears that they couldn't get info about their loved ones or give them supplies.

user.description: Journalist, human rights advocate, occasional Ebola survivor.
user.name: ashoka

text: BUT the very low cure rate in Ebola Treatment Units did make people say they were places you go to die, so I could understand ppl not going.

user.description: Journalist, human rights advocate, occasional Ebola survivor.
user.name: ashoka

text: I have a hard time imagining communities hiding Ebola patients en masse in Liberia, people are too frightened of the disease.

user.description: Journalist, human rights advocate, occasional Ebola survivor.
user.name: ashoka

text: I want to believe the Ebola awareness campaigns are working. Liberians are smart, at some point they realized the stakes were high.

user.description: Journalist, human rights advocate, occasional Ebola survivor.
user.name: ashoka

text: There are 2 possible scenarios in Liberia right now: people with Ebola are hiding, or awareness campaigns are working and infections r down

user.description: Journalist, human rights advocate, occasional Ebola survivor.
user.name: ashoka

text: When new treatment centers opened we all expected the holding center at Redemption to fill up in a week. It didn't. Nobody knew why.

user.description: Journalist, human rights advocate, occasional Ebola survivor.

text: Whether things were getting better or not was a huge debate even back in mid-September in Liberia.

text: There is no need for a 70% case fatality rate in Africa. That's about resources, not the inherent virulence of Ebola.

user.description: Journalist, human rights advocate, occasional Ebola survivor.

text: HCWs have to make tough calls re whether to risk self-infection by IVing patients, etc.

user.description: Journalist, human rights advocate, occasional Ebola survivor.
user.name: ashoka

text: Understandably, containing the spread of Ebola is priority. But finding ways to help the sick survive is also important.

user.description: Journalist, human rights advocate, occasional Ebola survivor.
user.name: ashoka

text: There are two key debates in the Ebola outbreak. 1. How to stop it, and 2. How to save the sick. Often the 1st debate eclipsed the 2nd.
